questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive jaw swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, and lifts the ear lobe. The histological image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Jaw Tumor. Jaw tumors, specifically tumors of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and not typically located in the region of the parotid gland. They are hard and not variable in consistency.
  • • Option A. Jaw Tumor.
  • • Option B. Dermoid cyst. Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors that often contain skin appendages (like hair follicles), and sometimes even hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and are often found on the face, neck, or ovary. While a dermoid cyst can appear on the face or neck, the clinical presentation and history given are not as suggestive of this diagnosis as it is for pleomorphic adenoma. They typically show indentation due to putty material.
  • • Option B. Dermoid cyst.
  • • Option D. Sebaceous cyst. Also known as an epidermal cyst , a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth that arises from blocked sebaceous glands. It often contains a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and show a black punctum. However, the clinical presentation and duration described more favorably match pleomorphic adenoma.
  • • Option D. Sebaceous cyst.
  • • epidermal cyst
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands most frequently arising out of the parotid.
  • • Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands most frequently arising out of the parotid.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of itching in vagina, discharge from vagina and dyspareunia. Best treatment option would be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vaginal estrogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presentation of vaginal itching, discharge, and dyspareunia in a 60-year-old woman is suggestive of atrophic vaginitis, a condition common in postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels leading to thinning and inflammation of the vaginal walls. Vaginal estrogen therapy is the most effective treatment for atrophic vaginitis, as it helps to restore the vaginal mucosa's thickness, elasticity, and secretions, alleviating the symptoms of itching, discharge, and dyspareunia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Vaginal metronidazole (A): This is used to treat bacterial vaginosis, which typically presents with a fishy-smelling vaginal discharge and may or may not include itching or irritation. The patient's symptoms and age make atrophic vaginitis more likely than bacterial vaginosis. Vaginal clindamycin (B): Similar to metronidazole, vaginal clindamycin is indicated for bacterial vaginosis, not for symptoms primarily due to atrophic changes in the vaginal mucosa. Vaginal clotrimazole (C): Clotrimazole is an antifungal medication used to treat yeast infections, characterized by thick, white vaginal discharge and significant itching. While itching is a common symptom, the overall presentation and the patient's age suggest that atrophic vaginitis is more likely the cause of her symptoms.
  • • Vaginal metronidazole (A): This is used to treat bacterial vaginosis, which typically presents with a fishy-smelling vaginal discharge and may or may not include itching or irritation. The patient's symptoms and age make atrophic vaginitis more likely than bacterial vaginosis.
  • • Vaginal metronidazole (A):
  • • Vaginal clindamycin (B): Similar to metronidazole, vaginal clindamycin is indicated for bacterial vaginosis, not for symptoms primarily due to atrophic changes in the vaginal mucosa.
  • • Vaginal clindamycin (B):
  • • Vaginal clotrimazole (C): Clotrimazole is an antifungal medication used to treat yeast infections, characterized by thick, white vaginal discharge and significant itching. While itching is a common symptom, the overall presentation and the patient's age suggest that atrophic vaginitis is more likely the cause of her symptoms.
  • • Vaginal clotrimazole (C):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective of this question is to identify the appropriate treatment for symptomatic atrophic vaginitis in a postmenopausal woman. Vaginal estrogen is the treatment of choice for relieving symptoms associated with atrophic changes in the vagina, such as itching, discharge, and dyspareunia. Understanding the differential diagnosis of vaginal symptoms based on the patient's age and clinical presentation is crucial for selecting the most appropriate therapy.

questions.text: A patient who uses contact lenses, is exhibiting the following clinical manifestations: persistent watering, redness, and a sensation of a foreign object in the eye over the last two months. What is the most likely diagnosis for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Giant papillary conjunctivitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute trachoma. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma. The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.
  • • Option A. Acute trachoma.
  • • Option B. Follicular conjunctivitis. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses. The image below shows follicles.
  • • Option B. Follicular conjunctivitis.
  • • Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer. The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.
  • • Option D.
  • • Spring catarrh

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant papillary conjunctivitis is an allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva, often associated with contact lens use, characterized by large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and symptoms such as persistent watering, redness, and a foreign body sensation.
  • ➤ Giant papillary conjunctivitis is an allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva, often associated with contact lens use, characterized by large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and symptoms such as persistent watering, redness, and a foreign body sensation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the motor unit?

options.label: A
options.text: Multiple motor nerve fibers innervating a single muscle fiber

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple motor nerve fibers innervating multiple muscle fibers

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Multiple muscle fibers innervated by a single motor nerve

questions.text: The difference between Apo-B48 and Apo-B100 which are synthesized from the mRNA is due to:
questions.correct_answer: C. Deamination of cytidine to uridine
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Deamination of Cytidine to Uridine

questions.text: A young female presents with burning sensation during urination, increased frequency, and urgency. Which fluoroquinolone should not be given to the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Moxifloxacin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Moxifloxacin should not be given to this patient. It is not recommended for the treatment of uncomplicated urinary tract infections (UTIs) due to limited urinary excretion and a higher risk of systemic side effects compared to other fluoroquinolones.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a commonly used fluoroquinolone for the treatment of UTIs.
  • • Option A. Ofloxacin:
  • • Option B. Ciprofloxacin : Ciprofloxacin is another commonly used fluoroquinolone for the treatment of UTIs.
  • • Option B. Ciprofloxacin
  • • Option D. Levofloxacin : Levofloxacin is also frequently used for the treatment of UTIs and is considered a suitable option for this patient.
  • • Option D. Levofloxacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selecting an appropriate antibiotic for urinary tract infections (UTIs) is crucial. Moxifloxacin, due to limited urinary excretion and a higher risk of systemic side effects, is not recommended for uncomplicated UTIs. Understanding the appropriate antibiotic choices based on antibiotic susceptibility and patient factors is essential for optimal patient care.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a head injury from being struck with a heavy rod during a street brawl. He is conscious upon examination and has a significant, dough-like swelling on the back of his head, confined to the occipital region. The skin over the swelling is intact, and the mass fluctuates upon palpation, suggesting a fluid collection beneath the skin. Based on the presentation and location of the injury, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The hematoma was located in the subcutaneous portion of the occipital bone.

options.label: B
options.text: The hematoma, although large, did not extend forward to the orbital margins.

options.label: C
options.text: The occipital belly of the occipitofrontalis arises from the lateral part of the superior nuchal line and inserts into the galea aponeurotica.

options.label: D
options.text: The occipitalis muscle is supplied by the facial nerve.

questions.correct_answer: D. The occipitalis muscle is supplied by the facial nerve.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The occipitalis muscle is supplied by the facial nerve.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The hematoma was located in the subcutaneous portion of the occipital bone . This statement is likely correct given the described characteristics of the swelling, suggesting a subcutaneous location rather than a deeper intracranial or subgaleal hematoma.
  • • Option A. The hematoma was located in the subcutaneous portion of the occipital bone
  • • Option B. The hematoma, although large, did not extend forward to the orbital margins . This statement is plausible as the occipital region's hematoma, by anatomical boundaries, would generally not extend anteriorly to the orbital margins due to the attachment of the galea aponeurotica and other connective tissue structures limiting the forward spread of a hematoma in the scalp.
  • • Option B. The hematoma, although large, did not extend forward to the orbital margins
  • • Option C. The occipital belly of the occipitofrontalis arises from the lateral part of the superior nuchal line and inserts into the galea aponeurotica . This statement is anatomically correct, describing the origin and insertion of the occipital belly of the occipitofrontalis muscle accurately.
  • • Option C. The occipital belly of the occipitofrontalis arises from the lateral part of the superior nuchal line and inserts into the galea aponeurotica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question underscores the importance of understanding head and neck anatomy, specifically the innervation of the occipitalis muscle and the anatomic boundaries that influence the spread of scalp hematomas. It also emphasizes the need to differentiate between various branches of the facial nerve and their respective areas of innervation, which is crucial for clinical assessments and interventions in facial and scalp injuries.
  • ➤ The question underscores the importance of understanding head and neck anatomy, specifically the innervation of the occipitalis muscle and the anatomic boundaries that influence the spread of scalp hematomas.
  • ➤ It also emphasizes the need to differentiate between various branches of the facial nerve and their respective areas of innervation, which is crucial for clinical assessments and interventions in facial and scalp injuries.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the clinic one week after undergoing an endovascular repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He complains of a new-onset purple discoloration of his right great toe and a lacy, non-blanching rash over his lower extremities. Laboratory tests reveal peripheral eosinophilia and elevated serum creatinine levels from his baseline, indicating acute kidney injury (AKI). There is no history of recent medication changes, trauma, or muscle pain. His medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and amlodipine. Based on the clinical presentation and recent medical history, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atheroembolic renal disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Contrast-induced AKI : This condition is characterized by a deterioration in renal function following exposure to contrast media, typically occurring within 48 hours of exposure. The absence of skin manifestations and eosinophilia makes this diagnosis less likely in the context of this clinical scenario. Option C. Rhabdomyolysis : This condition involves the breakdown of muscle tissue leading to the release of intracellular contents, including myoglobin, into the bloodstream. It can lead to AKI but is usually associated with muscle pain, weakness, and a significant elevation in creatine kinase (CK), none of which are described in the patient's presentation. Option D. Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) : AIN is usually drug-induced and presents with AKI, but it is also associated with rash, fever, and eosinophilia. However, the classic findings of atheroembolism, such as the purple toe and livedo reticularis, are not typical features of AIN.
  • • Option A. Contrast-induced AKI : This condition is characterized by a deterioration in renal function following exposure to contrast media, typically occurring within 48 hours of exposure. The absence of skin manifestations and eosinophilia makes this diagnosis less likely in the context of this clinical scenario.
  • • Option A. Contrast-induced AKI
  • • Option C. Rhabdomyolysis : This condition involves the breakdown of muscle tissue leading to the release of intracellular contents, including myoglobin, into the bloodstream. It can lead to AKI but is usually associated with muscle pain, weakness, and a significant elevation in creatine kinase (CK), none of which are described in the patient's presentation.
  • • Option C. Rhabdomyolysis
  • • Option D. Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) : AIN is usually drug-induced and presents with AKI, but it is also associated with rash, fever, and eosinophilia. However, the classic findings of atheroembolism, such as the purple toe and livedo reticularis, are not typical features of AIN.
  • • Option D. Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A research team is investigating the cellular uptake mechanisms of various hormones and vitamins in a laboratory setting. They are particularly interested in a process that allows cells to selectively internalize molecules by the invagination of the cell membrane to form vesicles. This process is critical for the uptake of certain molecules that are essential for cellular function but are present at low concentrations in the extracellular fluid. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which cells internalize these molecules?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Receptor-mediated endocytosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Receptor-mediated endocytosis is a highly selective cellular uptake mechanism where specific molecules (ligands) bind to receptors on the cell surface. Upon ligand binding, the cell membrane invaginates and forms a vesicle that internalizes the ligand-receptor complex. This process is crucial for the uptake of certain molecules that are present at low concentrations in the extracellular fluid, such as low-density lipoproteins (LDL), transferrin, and certain vitamins and hormones. The specificity of this process is conferred by the receptors, which recognize and bind only to certain ligands.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A) Phagocytosis: Phagocytosis is the process by which cells, particularly phagocytes like macrophages and neutrophils, engulf large particles or microorganisms. It is part of the cellular immune response and is not as selective as receptor-mediated endocytosis for small molecules. B) Pinocytosis: Pinocytosis, often referred to as "cell drinking," is a form of endocytosis where the cell ingests extracellular fluid and its dissolved solutes. Unlike receptor-mediated endocytosis, pinocytosis is not highly selective for specific molecules. D) Simple diffusion: Simple diffusion is the passive movement of molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration without the need for cellular energy or specific transport mechanisms. It does not involve the invagination of the cell membrane or the formation of vesicles.
  • • A) Phagocytosis: Phagocytosis is the process by which cells, particularly phagocytes like macrophages and neutrophils, engulf large particles or microorganisms. It is part of the cellular immune response and is not as selective as receptor-mediated endocytosis for small molecules.
  • • A) Phagocytosis:
  • • B) Pinocytosis: Pinocytosis, often referred to as "cell drinking," is a form of endocytosis where the cell ingests extracellular fluid and its dissolved solutes. Unlike receptor-mediated endocytosis, pinocytosis is not highly selective for specific molecules.
  • • B) Pinocytosis:
  • • D) Simple diffusion: Simple diffusion is the passive movement of molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration without the need for cellular energy or specific transport mechanisms. It does not involve the invagination of the cell membrane or the formation of vesicles.
  • • D) Simple diffusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand receptor-mediated endocytosis as a selective cellular uptake mechanism that allows cells to internalize specific molecules by binding to cell surface receptors, leading to the invagination of the cell membrane and formation of vesicles. Recognizing the difference between receptor-mediated endocytosis and other cellular uptake mechanisms, such as phagocytosis, pinocytosis, and simple diffusion, is crucial for understanding how cells interact with their environment and regulate the uptake of essential molecules.

questions.text: During a surgical rotation, a medical student is asked about the histological characteristics of the biliary tree. The student recalls that the epithelial lining of the common bile duct plays a crucial role in the transport of bile from the liver and gallbladder into the duodenum. Which type of epithelium is most likely to be found lining the common bile duct?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Simple columnar

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Stratified columnar . This type of epithelium is rare and is usually found in areas requiring protection from mechanical stress that also perform secretion, such as the conjunctiva of the eye, but it is not present in the common bile duct.
  • • Option A. Stratified columnar
  • • Option B. Stratified squamous . Stratified squamous epithelium is designed to protect against abrasion and is found in areas subjected to friction, like the skin, the esophagus, and the vagina, not within the common bile duct.
  • • Option B. Stratified squamous
  • • Option C. Simple cuboidal . Simple cuboidal epithelium is found in areas that require secretion and absorption but is more commonly associated with renal tubules and glands, not the lining of the common bile duct.
  • • Option C. Simple cuboidal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective of this question is to ensure the examinee understands the histology of the biliary tree. It is important to recognize that the common bile duct is lined with simple columnar epithelium, reflecting its role in the transport and modification of bile. Understanding the types of epithelial cells and their locations in the body is fundamental in pathology and when interpreting histological specimens.
  • ➤ The educational objective of this question is to ensure the examinee understands the histology of the biliary tree.
  • ➤ It is important to recognize that the common bile duct is lined with simple columnar epithelium, reflecting its role in the transport and modification of bile.
  • ➤ Understanding the types of epithelial cells and their locations in the body is fundamental in pathology and when interpreting histological specimens.

questions.text: A 10-year-old is experiencing difficulties in school due to trouble reading the blackboard from a distance. His teacher has observed him squinting and adjusting his posture to see better. Upon visiting a pediatric clinic, the examining ophthalmologist notes a significant cloudiness in the boy's corneas. Additional assessments indicate that while his cognitive abilities and growth are normal, he has a notably limited range of motion in his joints. His heart function is deemed normal. An enzyme assay reveals a deficiency in a particular lysosomal enzyme. Given these findings, which condition is most likely responsible for the boy's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Scheie syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Scheie syndrome, also known as MPS Type I-S, is a form of mucopolysaccharidosis that results from a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase. It is the mildest form of MPS I and is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, corneal clouding, and various degrees of skeletal involvement, including reduced joint mobility. Unlike more severe forms of MPS I (such as Hurler syndrome), cardiac involvement is typically minimal or absent in Scheie syndrome, and life expectancy can be near normal. The boy's presentation of corneal clouding, normal intelligence, and reduced joint mobility, with an absence of severe systemic involvement, is consistent with Scheie syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A) Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome: Also known as MPS VI, this condition is characterized by normal intelligence but significant skeletal deformities, corneal clouding, and often cardiac involvement. It differs from Scheie syndrome primarily in the severity of skeletal and cardiac manifestations. B) Hurler syndrome: MPS I-H (Hurler syndrome) is the most severe form of mucopolysaccharidosis type I, characterized by developmental delay, gargoylism, airway obstruction, corneal clouding, and hepatosplenomegaly. The normal intelligence noted in the patient makes Hurler syndrome less likely. D) Tay-Sachs disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A, leading to accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neurons. It presents with developmental delay, cherry-red spots on the macula, and neurodegeneration. The absence of neurological symptoms and the specific corneal findings make this diagnosis unlikely.
  • • A) Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome: Also known as MPS VI, this condition is characterized by normal intelligence but significant skeletal deformities, corneal clouding, and often cardiac involvement. It differs from Scheie syndrome primarily in the severity of skeletal and cardiac manifestations.
  • • A) Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome:
  • • B) Hurler syndrome: MPS I-H (Hurler syndrome) is the most severe form of mucopolysaccharidosis type I, characterized by developmental delay, gargoylism, airway obstruction, corneal clouding, and hepatosplenomegaly. The normal intelligence noted in the patient makes Hurler syndrome less likely.
  • • B) Hurler syndrome:
  • • D) Tay-Sachs disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A, leading to accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neurons. It presents with developmental delay, cherry-red spots on the macula, and neurodegeneration. The absence of neurological symptoms and the specific corneal findings make this diagnosis unlikely.
  • • D) Tay-Sachs disease:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize the clinical presentation and distinguishing features of Scheie syndrome (MPS I-S), including corneal clouding, normal intelligence, and reduced joint mobility, without severe systemic involvement. Understanding the differences between various types of mucopolysaccharidoses and other lysosomal storage disorders is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A medical student is conducting a microbiology experiment to understand the growth characteristics of a particular bacterial species. The student uses two different types of media: a standard growth medium, which supports the growth of many microorganisms without favouring any particular type, and an enrichment medium, which contains specific nutrients to support the growth of a particular microorganism or group of microorganisms. After incubating bacterial cultures in both types of media, the student is asked to compare the growth patterns observed. Which of the following best describes the difference in bacterial growth in an enrichment medium compared to a standard growth medium?

options.label: A
options.text: Faster lag phase in enrichment medium

options.label: B
options.text: Slower log phase in enrichment medium

options.label: C
options.text: Higher bacterial count at stationary phase in enrichment medium

options.label: D
options.text: Earlier death phase in enrichment medium

questions.correct_answer: C. Higher bacterial count at stationary phase in enrichment medium
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Higher bacterial count at stationary phase in enrichment medium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Faster lag phase in enrichment medium is not necessarily true, as the lag phase is a period of adaptation and does not always correlate with the richness of the medium.
  • • Option A. Faster lag phase in enrichment medium
  • • Option B. Slower log phase in the enrichment medium is incorrect, as enrichment media are designed to facilitate, not hinder, bacterial growth.
  • • Option B. Slower log phase in the enrichment medium
  • • Option D. Earlier death phase in the enrichment medium is also incorrect. The death phase is determined by factors like nutrient depletion and waste accumulation, which are not directly influenced by the enrichment of the medium.
  • • Option D. Earlier death phase in the enrichment medium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enhanced bacterial growth in enrichment media compared to standard media is vital in microbiological studies. Bacteria like E. coli, when grown in enrichment media, demonstrate a higher bacterial count at the stationary phase due to the provision of essential nutrients and favourable growth conditions.
  • ➤ Enhanced bacterial growth in enrichment media compared to standard media is vital in microbiological studies.
  • ➤ Bacteria like E. coli, when grown in enrichment media, demonstrate a higher bacterial count at the stationary phase due to the provision of essential nutrients and favourable growth conditions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the psychiatry clinic referred by her primary care physician due to episodes of sudden travel away from home with inability to recall her past. She reports finding herself in different places without knowing how she got there, and sometimes she is told she acts like a different person during these episodes. She has no recollection of these events. Her medical history is significant for childhood trauma. She denies substance use and her physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dissociative Amnesia with Fugue

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B) Dissociative Identity Disorder. This disorder is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct personality states or identities that recurrently take control of behaviour. Although the patient exhibits change in identity, the key feature of sudden, unexpected travel and amnesia is more indicative of Dissociative Amnesia with Fugue.
  • • Option B) Dissociative Identity Disorder.
  • • Option C) Borderline Personality Disorder. This disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, and marked impulsivity. While patients with borderline personality disorder may experience dissociative symptoms during stress, the primary symptoms described in the vignette are more consistent with a dissociative disorder.
  • • Option C) Borderline Personality Disorder.
  • • Option D) Schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is a psychiatric disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and/or grossly disorganized or catatonic behaviour. The symptoms described in the vignette do not include these hallmark features of schizophrenia.
  • • Option D) Schizophrenia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize and diagnose Dissociative Amnesia with Fugue, it is important to identify the characteristic pattern of sudden, unexpected travel away from home with subsequent amnesia for the event. Understanding the distinction between Dissociative Amnesia with Fugue and other disorders such as Dissociative Identity Disorder, Borderline Personality Disorder, and Schizophrenia is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ To recognize and diagnose Dissociative Amnesia with Fugue, it is important to identify the characteristic pattern of sudden, unexpected travel away from home with subsequent amnesia for the event.
  • ➤ Understanding the distinction between Dissociative Amnesia with Fugue and other disorders such as Dissociative Identity Disorder, Borderline Personality Disorder, and Schizophrenia is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling off his bicycle and landing on his outstretched hand. He is in considerable pain and reports swelling in the area around his elbow. On physical examination, the elbow shows tenderness, noticeable deformity, and a restricted range of motion. Radiographic imaging of the elbow reveals a fracture in the vicinity of the elbow joint. To ascertain the specifics of the injury and devise a suitable management plan, the treating physician evaluates the alignment of key anatomical landmarks around the elbow. In the context of elbow injuries, the preservation of the alignment of three bony points around the elbow is crucial for diagnosis. Which of the following conditions is characterized by maintaining this tri-point bony relationship around the elbow?

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus

questions.correct_answer: A. Supracondylar fracture of the humerus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supracondylar fracture of the humerus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Dislocation of the elbow. This condition typically results in a clear disruption of the normal alignment of the elbow joint, often easily identifiable on physical examination and radiographs, disrupting the three bony point relationship.
  • • Option B. Dislocation of the elbow.
  • • Option C. Fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus. Such fractures can affect the stability of the elbow joint and may disrupt the normal relationship of the three bony points, depending on the severity and displacement of the fracture.
  • • Option C. Fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus.
  • • Option D. Intercondylar fracture of the humerus. This involves the area between the condyles of the humerus and can significantly disrupt the anatomy of the elbow joint, including the relationship of the three bony landmarks.
  • • Option D. Intercondylar fracture of the humerus.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question tests the understanding of common elbow injuries in pediatric patients, focusing on the diagnostic significance of the three bony point relationship around the elbow. In supracondylar fractures of the humerus, despite the fracture, the alignment of the lateral epicondyle, medial epicondyle, and olecranon is often maintained. This contrasts with elbow dislocations and other fractures, such as lateral condyle or intercondylar fractures, which may disrupt this alignment. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for appropriate management, including the decision between operative and non-operative treatments.
  • ➤ The question tests the understanding of common elbow injuries in pediatric patients, focusing on the diagnostic significance of the three bony point relationship around the elbow.
  • ➤ In supracondylar fractures of the humerus, despite the fracture, the alignment of the lateral epicondyle, medial epicondyle, and olecranon is often maintained.
  • ➤ This contrasts with elbow dislocations and other fractures, such as lateral condyle or intercondylar fractures, which may disrupt this alignment.
  • ➤ Recognizing these patterns is crucial for appropriate management, including the decision between operative and non-operative treatments.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with weakness in his right arm and hand after using crutches for six weeks due to a leg injury. He reports difficulty with arm extension, wrist drop, and sensory loss over the dorsal aspect of his hand. Physical examination reveals diminished grip strength and decreased sensation over the radial nerve distribution. The patient's history indicates prolonged pressure on the axillary region due to crutch use. Based on the patient's symptoms and history, which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question assesses the understanding of brachial plexus injuries, specifically crutch palsy, which affects the posterior cord. It highlights the importance of recognizing the clinical manifestations of radial nerve dysfunction, such as wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsal hand, and differentiating it from injuries to other parts of the brachial plexus. Understanding the anatomical relationship between crutch use and the brachial plexus is crucial for diagnosing and managing crutch-related neuropathies.

  • ➤ It highlights the importance of recognizing the clinical manifestations of radial nerve dysfunction, such as wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsal hand, and differentiating it from injuries to other parts of the brachial plexus.
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical relationship between crutch use and the brachial plexus is crucial for diagnosing and managing crutch-related neuropathies.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of bloody stools and abdominal pain. His medical history is significant for the removal of several colon polyps found during a screening colonoscopy at age 16. The patient mentions that his father and older brother have also had numerous polyps and underwent colectomies. Physical examination is unremarkable. Genetic testing is considered to confirm the diagnosis. Which gene is most commonly mutated in the condition suspected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) APC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. PTEN : Mutations in the PTEN gene are associated with Cowden syndrome, which is characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk for breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers, not primarily colorectal polyps. Option B. MUTYH : Mutations in MUTYH are linked with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP), an autosomal recessive condition that also predisposes to colorectal polyps and cancer but would not typically present with a strong autosomal dominant family history as in this case. Option D. BLM : Mutations in the BLM gene cause Bloom syndrome, characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin lesions, and an increased risk of various cancers, but not specifically associated with the development of numerous adenomatous polyps as in FAP.
  • • Option A. PTEN : Mutations in the PTEN gene are associated with Cowden syndrome, which is characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk for breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers, not primarily colorectal polyps.

  • • Option B. MUTYH
  • • Option D. BLM : Mutations in the BLM gene cause Bloom syndrome, characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin lesions, and an increased risk of various cancers, but not specifically associated with the development of numerous adenomatous polyps as in FAP.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss presents to a fertility clinic for evaluation. Her medical history is significant only for these pregnancy losses, and she has no other known health issues. After a comprehensive workup, imaging studies confirm the diagnosis of a bicornuate uterus, a congenital uterine anomaly. Given her history and the findings, the fertility specialist discusses potential management options, including surgical intervention. When should surgical reconstruction of a bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) be considered for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus

options.label: D
options.text: For women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause except their uterine anomaly

questions.correct_answer: D. For women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause except their uterine anomaly
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) For women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause except their uterine anomaly

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Surgical reconstruction of a bicornuate uterus, such as through Strassman metroplasty, is typically reserved for women who have experienced recurrent pregnancy loss with no other identifiable cause except for their uterine anomaly. This procedure aims to create a single uterine cavity, potentially reducing the risk of future pregnancy losses. It is not routinely recommended for all women with a bicornuate uterus, as many can have successful pregnancies without surgical intervention.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Only for complete bicornuate anomalies (A): While more severe anomalies might warrant consideration for surgery, the indication for surgery is more strongly correlated with reproductive outcomes, such as recurrent pregnancy loss, rather than the anatomical extent of the bicornuate uterus. In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus (B): Not all women with a bicornuate uterus require surgery. Many can achieve and maintain successful pregnancies without intervention. Surgery is considered based on obstetric history, particularly recurrent pregnancy loss, and not merely the diagnosis of a bicornuate uterus. Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus (C): This statement is incorrect. Strassman metroplasty is indeed a surgical technique used to correct a bicornuate uterus by uniting the separate uterine cavities into a single cavity.
  • • Only for complete bicornuate anomalies (A): While more severe anomalies might warrant consideration for surgery, the indication for surgery is more strongly correlated with reproductive outcomes, such as recurrent pregnancy loss, rather than the anatomical extent of the bicornuate uterus.
  • • Only for complete bicornuate anomalies (A):
  • • In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus (B): Not all women with a bicornuate uterus require surgery. Many can achieve and maintain successful pregnancies without intervention. Surgery is considered based on obstetric history, particularly recurrent pregnancy loss, and not merely the diagnosis of a bicornuate uterus.
  • • In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus (B):
  • • Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus (C): This statement is incorrect. Strassman metroplasty is indeed a surgical technique used to correct a bicornuate uterus by uniting the separate uterine cavities into a single cavity.
  • • Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus (C):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective of this question is to understand the indications for surgical correction of a bicornuate uterus. Strassman metroplasty is considered for women with a bicornuate uterus who have suffered recurrent pregnancy losses with no other identifiable cause. The decision for surgery is based on clinical outcomes rather than the mere presence of the anatomical anomaly.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal bloating presents to the gastroenterology clinic. She reports that her symptoms seem to worsen after consuming bread and pasta. Physical examination is unremarkable, and celiac serology tests are positive. A biopsy of the small intestine is performed, which shows characteristic features of celiac disease. Which of the following morphological features would you NOT expect to find on the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria

questions.correct_answer: C. Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes . This is a hallmark feature of celiac disease, representing an immune response to gluten.
  • • Option A. Increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes
  • • Option B. Increase in crypt:villous ratio . Celiac disease often presents with villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia, which leads to an increased crypt: villous ratio.
  • • Option B. Increase in crypt:villous ratio
  • • Option D. Elongated hyperplastic and tortuous crypts . This finding represents the crypt hyperplasia that occurs as part of the characteristic mucosal response in celiac disease.
  • • Option D. Elongated hyperplastic and tortuous crypts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to identify the histopathological features of celiac disease. Recognizing these features can assist in the diagnosis of celiac disease, which is characterized by an increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes, an increased crypt:villous ratio, and elongated hyperplastic and tortuous crypts. Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules are not a feature of celiac disease but suggest a diagnosis of Whipple's disease. Understanding the morphological changes seen in celiac disease is critical for medical students and can guide appropriate dietary and medical management of affected patients.
  • ➤ The educational objective is to identify the histopathological features of celiac disease.
  • ➤ Recognizing these features can assist in the diagnosis of celiac disease, which is characterized by an increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes, an increased crypt:villous ratio, and elongated hyperplastic and tortuous crypts.
  • ➤ Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules are not a feature of celiac disease but suggest a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.
  • ➤ Understanding the morphological changes seen in celiac disease is critical for medical students and can guide appropriate dietary and medical management of affected patients.

questions.text: An 18-year girl presents with a painful enlarged Bartholin cyst. She is a 1 st year medical student and is curious as to how this developed. Bartholin gland duct cysts form in direct response to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gland duct obstruction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bartholin gland duct cysts typically develop as a result of the obstruction of the Bartholin gland duct. The Bartholin glands are located on each side of the vaginal opening and secrete fluid that helps lubricate the vagina. When the duct of a Bartholin gland becomes obstructed, fluid can back up into the gland, leading to swelling and the formation of a cyst. This obstruction can be caused by infection, inflammation, or physical blockage, but the cyst itself is directly due to the obstruction of the duct.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Vulvar irritation (A): While vulvar irritation can lead to discomfort and may be associated with conditions affecting the vulva, it does not directly cause Bartholin gland duct cysts. Irritation can exacerbate symptoms of an existing cyst but is not a primary cause. Cervical gonorrhea (B): Gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection, can infect the Bartholin glands and potentially lead to abscess formation, but the primary cause of a Bartholin duct cyst is the obstruction of the duct, not the infection itself. Chronic lichen sclerosus (D): Chronic lichen sclerosus is a skin condition that affects the genital area and can cause itching, pain, and scarring. While it can lead to changes in the vulvar tissue, it does not directly result in the formation of Bartholin gland duct cysts.
  • • Vulvar irritation (A): While vulvar irritation can lead to discomfort and may be associated with conditions affecting the vulva, it does not directly cause Bartholin gland duct cysts. Irritation can exacerbate symptoms of an existing cyst but is not a primary cause.
  • • Vulvar irritation (A):
  • • Cervical gonorrhea (B): Gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection, can infect the Bartholin glands and potentially lead to abscess formation, but the primary cause of a Bartholin duct cyst is the obstruction of the duct, not the infection itself.
  • • Cervical gonorrhea (B):
  • • Chronic lichen sclerosus (D): Chronic lichen sclerosus is a skin condition that affects the genital area and can cause itching, pain, and scarring. While it can lead to changes in the vulvar tissue, it does not directly result in the formation of Bartholin gland duct cysts.
  • • Chronic lichen sclerosus (D):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective of this question is to understand the pathophysiology of Bartholin gland duct cysts, emphasizing that the primary cause is the obstruction of the gland duct. Recognizing the underlying mechanism aids in the accurate diagnosis and management of this common gynecological condition. It is also important to differentiate between the causes of the cyst formation and conditions that may mimic or exacerbate the symptoms of a Bartholin cyst.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents to his primary care physician for a routine check-up. He mentions he has been trying to manage his diet and exercise but admits to occasional indulgences. His medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. On review of systems, he reports intermittent claudication and has a history of transient ischemic attacks. His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease. Given his history and symptomatology, which hormone abnormality is most commonly associated with stroke, peripheral vascular disease, and atherosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Insulin deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hyperestrogenemia. While estrogen has been implicated in various vascular effects, hyperestrogenemia is not commonly associated with stroke, peripheral vascular disease, and atherosclerosis. Estrogen is typically considered to have a protective effect against atherosclerosis, especially in premenopausal women.
  • • Option B. Hyperestrogenemia.
  • • Option C. Hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism can lead to hyperlipidemia and a mild increase in the risk of atherosclerosis. However, it is not as strongly associated with stroke and peripheral vascular disease as insulin deficiency.
  • • Option C. Hypothyroidism.
  • • Option D. Progesterone. Progesterone, like estrogen, has various effects on the vascular system, but it is not primarily associated with stroke, peripheral vascular disease, and atherosclerosis in the context of hormone abnormalities.
  • • Option D. Progesterone.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the association between insulin deficiency and an increased risk of macrovascular complications such as stroke, peripheral vascular disease, and atherosclerosis. Recognizing the role of insulin in vascular health is essential for managing patients with diabetes mellitus and for preventing the development of these serious complications.
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand the association between insulin deficiency and an increased risk of macrovascular complications such as stroke, peripheral vascular disease, and atherosclerosis.
  • ➤ Recognizing the role of insulin in vascular health is essential for managing patients with diabetes mellitus and for preventing the development of these serious complications.

questions.text: An episode of marked chest pain lasting for 4 hours brings a 52-year-old man to the emergency room. He is found to have an elevated serum troponin. An angiogram reveals a complete blockage of the left circumflex artery 2 cm from its origin. Which of the following substances would you most expect to be elaborated around the region of tissue damage in the next 3 days as an initial response to promote healing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vascular endothelial growth factor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Histamine . Histamine is released immediately following tissue injury and contributes to the acute inflammatory response by dilating blood vessels and making them more permeable. While histamine plays a role in the initial inflammatory phase, it is not specifically involved in the later stages of healing, such as angiogenesis and tissue repair, which occur over the days following an AMI.
  • • Option A. Histamine
  • • Option B. Immunoglobulin G (IgG). IgG is an antibody that plays a crucial role in the body's immune response to infection. While the immune system is involved in the healing process after an AMI, IgG itself is not specifically elaborated to promote healing in the context of myocardial infarction.
  • • Option B. Immunoglobulin G (IgG).
  • • Option C. Complement component C3b. C3b is a part of the complement system, which helps clear pathogens and damaged cells. It can opsonize pathogens and damaged cells for removal by phagocytes. While the complement system may be activated in response to tissue damage and inflammation, C3b is not directly involved in the healing and repair processes such as angiogenesis that are critical in the days following an AMI.
  • • Option C. Complement component C3b.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to understand the role of VEGF in the healing process following an acute myocardial infarction. VEGF is crucial for promoting angiogenesis, which is essential for the formation of new blood vessels in the damaged heart tissue. This process is vital for supporting tissue repair and regeneration by improving blood supply to the affected area. Understanding the substances involved in post-infarction healing can help guide therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes after myocardial infarction.
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to understand the role of VEGF in the healing process following an acute myocardial infarction.
  • ➤ VEGF is crucial for promoting angiogenesis, which is essential for the formation of new blood vessels in the damaged heart tissue.
  • ➤ This process is vital for supporting tissue repair and regeneration by improving blood supply to the affected area.
  • ➤ Understanding the substances involved in post-infarction healing can help guide therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes after myocardial infarction.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is reviewing data from a recent outbreak of acute respiratory illness in a large urban high school. The outbreak was traced back to a single day when an infected individual attended a crowded indoor assembly. Within a short period, a significant number of students and staff developed symptoms, but the outbreak subsided almost as quickly as it began, with no new cases reported after the initial wave. Based on these observations, which of the following characteristics are true of this outbreak, suggesting it was a point source epidemic? The outbreak exhibited a rapid rise and fall in the number of cases. The outbreak was due solely to an infectious agent. The outbreak was explosive, with a large number of cases occurring in a short timeframe. The outbreak had a high secondary attack rate. There was no secondary wave of infection following the initial outbreak.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Single exposure common vehicle outbreak: Also known as ‘Point Source Epidemic,’ where exposure to disease agent is brief and essentially simultaneous
  • ➤ Epidemic Curve rises and falls rapidly, with no secondary waves Explosive: Clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time All cases develop within one incubation period of disease
  • ➤ Epidemic Curve rises and falls rapidly, with no secondary waves
  • ➤ Explosive: Clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time
  • ➤ All cases develop within one incubation period of disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fatigue, pallor, and dark urine. She has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and recently started a new medication. Physical examination is notable for jaundice and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show anemia, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and low haptoglobin levels. Urinalysis reveals the presence of hemoglobin without red blood cells. Based on these findings, she is diagnosed with intravascular hemolysis. Which of the following is a prominent feature of intravascular hemolysis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hemoglobinuria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hemoglobinuria is a prominent feature of intravascular hemolysis, where the destruction of red blood cells occurs within the blood vessels. The release of hemoglobin into the plasma exceeds the binding capacity of haptoglobin, leading to free hemoglobin filtration by the kidneys and its appearance in the urine. Hemoglobinuria is indicative of significant intravascular hemolysis and can lead to dark-colored urine, as described in the patient's presentation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . While an increase in unconjugated bilirubin can occur in hemolysis due to the breakdown of heme, it is not as specific to intravascular hemolysis as hemoglobinuria.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B . An increase in aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels can be seen in various conditions, including liver disease and muscle injury, and is not specifically indicative of intravascular hemolysis.
  • • Option B
  • • Option D. Increased urobilinogen in urine can occur in hemolytic processes due to increased bilirubin metabolism; however, it is not as prominent or specific a feature of intravascular hemolysis as hemoglobinuria.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question aims to highlight hemoglobinuria as a key clinical feature of intravascular hemolysis, which distinguishes it from other types of hemolysis where red blood cell destruction occurs primarily in the reticuloendothelial system (extravascular hemolysis). Recognizing hemoglobinuria as a diagnostic clue can help guide the evaluation and management of patients presenting with hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has had worsening orthopnea for the past 3 years. She is unable to tolerate strenuous exercise. She has had increasing difficulty with swallowing for the past year. On physical examination, she has a cardiac murmur. She is afebrile. Based upon the gross appearances of her heart shown here, which of the following is the most likely the underlying cause for her illness?
questions.correct_answer: A. Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. While diabetes can lead to cardiovascular complications, it typically does not cause the valvular damage seen in the image. Diabetes is more commonly associated with coronary artery disease and cardiomyopathy.
  • • Option B. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.
  • • Option C. Congenital anomaly. If the woman had a congenital anomaly severe enough to cause her symptoms, it would likely have been detected much earlier in life. While congenital anomalies can present in adulthood, they often do so in the context of a known history of heart issues.
  • • Option C. Congenital anomaly.
  • • Option D. Staphylococcus aureus infection. This type of infection can lead to acute bacterial endocarditis, which can also cause vegetations on the valves. However, the patient's presentation over years and lack of acute symptoms like high fever make an acute infection less likely.
  • • Option D. Staphylococcus aureus infection.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand that the chronic symptoms of heart failure and difficulty swallowing, in combination with findings suggestive of valve abnormalities, are most consistent with a history of rheumatic fever leading to rheumatic heart disease. This is especially likely in the context of a past Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection. It is crucial to take into account the full clinical presentation, including the patient's history and symptoms, along with physical and imaging findings, to arrive at the correct diagnosis.
  • ➤ The educational objective is to understand that the chronic symptoms of heart failure and difficulty swallowing, in combination with findings suggestive of valve abnormalities, are most consistent with a history of rheumatic fever leading to rheumatic heart disease.
  • ➤ This is especially likely in the context of a past Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection. It is crucial to take into account the full clinical presentation, including the patient's history and symptoms, along with physical and imaging findings, to arrive at the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of drooping of the upper eyelid in his right eye. He reports a gradual onset of this condition over the past few weeks, along with other symptoms like decreased sweating on the right side of his face and a constricted pupil in the same eye. Upon further examination, the ophthalmologist suspects Horner's syndrome. What can be the preferred management for ptosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fasanella servat operation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fasanella servat operation is done for mild ptosis (< 2 mm) caused by Horner's syndrome.
  • ➤ Fasanella servat operation is done for mild ptosis (< 2 mm) caused by Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for her third trimester prenatal visit. She has no known medical conditions and is experiencing a healthy pregnancy. What should be the focus of antenatal care during the third trimester?

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Assessment of maternal blood pressure and urine protein

Ans. C) Monitoring fetal growth and well-being

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a history of blurred vision and eye pain in her left eye for the past few months. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes a pigmented lesion on the iris with irregular borders and a raised appearance. The pupil is slightly distorted, and there is mild dilation of the pupil. The intraocular pressure is within normal limits. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable . A T1-weighted MRI is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Metastasis. Ocular metastases are more common than primary ocular tumors, but they typically involve the choroid rather than the iris. When metastases involve the iris, they usually present with less pigmentation and more diffuse involvement rather than a discrete, pigmented, and raised lesion.
  • • Option A. Metastasis.
  • • Option B. Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV). PHPV is a congenital anomaly characterized by a failure of the hyaloid vascular system to regress and can lead to a range of ocular abnormalities, including microphthalmia, cataract, and glaucoma. It does not present as a pigmented iris lesion in adults.
  • • Option B. Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV).
  • • Option D. Retinoblastoma. This is a primary malignant tumor of the retina, most commonly seen in children. It does not present as a pigmented lesion of the iris in adults. Additionally, retinoblastoma typically presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and may lead to strabismus, but not typically as an iris lesion in adults.
  • • Option D. Retinoblastoma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key aspects of this case point towards a diagnosis of iris melanoma . The patient's age, the description of the lesion (pigmented with irregular borders and raised appearance), and the slight distortion of the pupil are classic signs of iris melanoma. MRI findings supporting this diagnosis add further evidence. In contrast, metastasis to the iris would likely present differently, PHPV is a congenital condition not applicable to adults, and retinoblastoma is primarily a pediatric retinal cancer, making melanoma the most likely diagnosis given the clinical presentation.
  • ➤ The key aspects of this case point towards a diagnosis of iris melanoma .
  • ➤ iris melanoma
  • ➤ The patient's age, the description of the lesion (pigmented with irregular borders and raised appearance), and the slight distortion of the pupil are classic signs of iris melanoma.
  • ➤ MRI findings supporting this diagnosis add further evidence.
  • ➤ In contrast, metastasis to the iris would likely present differently, PHPV is a congenital condition not applicable to adults, and retinoblastoma is primarily a pediatric retinal cancer, making melanoma the most likely diagnosis given the clinical presentation.

questions.text: A public health officer is evaluating various environmental factors to ensure the health and safety of the community. As part of this role, the officer must use different indices to measure the quality of air, water, soil, and food products. One particular index, the Saturation Index, is employed by the officer in this process. This index is a measure that incorporates several parameters to assess the quality of a specific environmental aspect. Which of the following best describes the use of the Saturation Index?

options.label: A
options.text: Used to assess the Air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants

options.label: B
options.text: Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH

options.label: C
options.text: Used to assess the Soil quality that whether it is good for growing crops

options.label: D
options.text: Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it

questions.correct_answer: B. Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option (a) Air Quality: Air quality is typically assessed using different indices, such as the Air Quality Index (AQI), which measures pollutants like ozone, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen dioxide. Option (c) Soil Quality: Soil quality assessments involve a variety of indices that evaluate factors such as nutrient content, pH, organic matter content, and soil structure, but not the Saturation Index. Option (d) Milk Quality : Milk quality is generally assessed by somatic cell count, bacterial count, and composition (fat, protein, etc.), not by the Saturation Index.
  • • Option (a) Air Quality: Air quality is typically assessed using different indices, such as the Air Quality Index (AQI), which measures pollutants like ozone, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen dioxide.
  • • Option (a) Air Quality:
  • • Option (c) Soil Quality: Soil quality assessments involve a variety of indices that evaluate factors such as nutrient content, pH, organic matter content, and soil structure, but not the Saturation Index.
  • • Option (c) Soil Quality:
  • • Option (d) Milk Quality : Milk quality is generally assessed by somatic cell count, bacterial count, and composition (fat, protein, etc.), not by the Saturation Index.
  • • Option (d) Milk Quality

  • ➤ Langlier’s Saturation Index (LSI)
  • ➤ Langlier’s Saturation Index (LSI)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents to the emergency department with new-onset, worsening chest pain, breathlessness, and diaphoresis that began 1 hour ago. His initial ECG shows ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, and ST depression in leads I and aVL. He receives a loading dose of antiplatelets and anticoagulants and is referred for further management within 15 minutes. Considering the need for rapid reperfusion therapy, which of the following drugs is least effective in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Streptokinase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Reteplase : Reteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator with a relatively short half-life, allowing for rapid administration. It is effective in achieving coronary artery reperfusion in STEMI patients. Option B. Tenecteplase : Tenecteplase is a genetically engineered variant of tissue plasminogen activator with enhanced fibrin specificity and longer half-life, allowing for single-bolus administration. It is associated with high efficacy in achieving reperfusion and has a favorable safety profile. Option D. Alteplase : Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator that directly converts plasminogen to plasmin, leading to clot dissolution. It is widely used and effective in the treatment of acute myocardial infarction, with a well-established efficacy and safety profile.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to recurrent episodes of melena and a rash that has been persistent for several weeks. The parents also report that they have noticed small, red spots on his skin, which seem to appear without any injury or trauma. Physical examination reveals a dermatitis-like rash and multiple petechiae across the boy's body. Laboratory tests show a low platelet count, while red blood cell and white blood cell counts are within normal ranges. Given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic investigation to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) WASP gene study

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Anti-platelet antibodies. This test is used to investigate immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), where the body's immune system mistakenly targets and destroys platelets. While ITP could present with similar symptoms, the presence of dermatitis and the specific pattern of symptoms in this case make WAS more likely.
  • • Option A. Anti-platelet antibodies.
  • • Option B. Bone marrow examination. This investigation is crucial for evaluating bone marrow function and ruling out bone marrow disorders such as leukemia or aplastic anemia. In this scenario, the normal red and white blood cell counts make primary bone marrow disorders less likely, and the clinical picture points more towards a genetic syndrome affecting platelets.
  • • Option B. Bone marrow examination.
  • • Option D. Platelet function analyser. This test assesses platelet function and is used to diagnose disorders of platelet function. While this could be part of the workup for a child with bleeding episodes, it would not be diagnostic for WAS, which is characterized by a combination of symptoms including immunodeficiency and eczema, in addition to platelet issues.
  • • Option D. Platelet function analyser.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question aims to test the examinee's ability to recognize the clinical presentation of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome and understand the appropriate diagnostic steps. The WASP gene study is key to confirming the diagnosis of WAS, distinguishing it from other causes of thrombocytopenia and bleeding disorders in children. This question emphasizes the importance of integrating clinical findings with targeted genetic testing to diagnose inherited disorders accurately.
  • ➤ The question aims to test the examinee's ability to recognize the clinical presentation of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome and understand the appropriate diagnostic steps.
  • ➤ The WASP gene study is key to confirming the diagnosis of WAS, distinguishing it from other causes of thrombocytopenia and bleeding disorders in children.
  • ➤ This question emphasizes the importance of integrating clinical findings with targeted genetic testing to diagnose inherited disorders accurately.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of hypertension is being treated with metoprolol. During a routine follow-up, her blood pressure readings are still above the target range, prompting the addition of verapamil to her treatment regimen. Shortly after the initiation of verapamil, she presents to the emergency department with dizziness and fatigue. Which of the following is the most likely complication of adding verapamil to a patient already receiving metoprolol?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atrial fibrillation. While both metoprolol and verapamil can be used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, their combination is not typically associated with the induction of atrial fibrillation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Atrial fibrillation.
  • • Option C. Torsades de pointes. This is a specific type of ventricular tachycardia associated with prolonged QT interval, more commonly related to drugs that block the potassium channels. Neither metoprolol nor verapamil is primarily associated with this adverse effect.
  • • Option C.
  • • Torsades de pointes.
  • • Option D. Tachycardia. Both metoprolol and verapamil are more likely to cause bradycardia rather than tachycardia as they both have heart rate-lowering effects.
  • • Option D.
  • • Tachycardia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question highlights the importance of understanding drug interactions, especially in cardiovascular pharmacotherapy. The combination of a beta-blocker like metoprolol and a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker like verapamil can lead to excessive suppression of cardiac conduction and heart rate, resulting in bradycardia and AV block. Clinicians should closely monitor patients when combining these medications and consider alternatives if there is a high risk of adverse effects.
  • ➤ The question highlights the importance of understanding drug interactions, especially in cardiovascular pharmacotherapy.
  • ➤ The combination of a beta-blocker like metoprolol and a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker like verapamil can lead to excessive suppression of cardiac conduction and heart rate, resulting in bradycardia and AV block.
  • ➤ Clinicians should closely monitor patients when combining these medications and consider alternatives if there is a high risk of adverse effects.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was trying to pour water from a glass jar into his cup but the glass jar slipped off his fingers and fell down. As he tried to gather the broken pieces of glass, he noticed that one of those glass pieces deeply pierced the skin on the front of his right wrist. On examination, a small wound was present in the front of his forearm and the palmaris longus tendon had been severed. The thumb was laterally rotated and adducted, and the boy was unable to oppose his thumb to the other fingers. There was loss of skin sensation over the lateral half of the palm and the palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers. The following facts concerning this patient are correct except:

options.label: A
options.text: Adduction of thumb is caused by adductor pollicis that is supplied by ulnar nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Opposition of thumb is produced by opponens pollicis that is innervated by median nerve

options.label: C
options.text: The median nerve lies in the interval between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus just proximal to the wrist joint

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory loss of the distal part of the dorsal surfaces of the lateral three and a half fingers was present

questions.correct_answer: C. The median nerve lies in the interval between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus just proximal to the wrist joint
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The median nerve lies in the interval between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus just proximal to the wrist joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Adduction of thumb is caused by adductor pollicis that is supplied by ulnar nerve . The median nerve supplies the thenar muscles of hand (Thenar muscles – Flexor pollicis brevis, Abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis).
  • • Option A.
  • • Adduction of thumb is caused by adductor pollicis that is supplied by ulnar nerve
  • • Option B . Opposition of thumb is produced by opponens pollicis that is innervated by median nerve . First and second lumbricals are innervated by the median nerve; third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • • Option B
  • • Opposition of thumb is produced by opponens pollicis that is innervated by median nerve
  • • Option D. Sensory loss of the distal part of the dorsal surfaces of the lateral three and a half fingers was present . The median nerve gives cutaneous branches to supply the lateral surface of hand and lateral 3 ½ digits.
  • • Option D.
  • • Sensory loss of the distal part of the dorsal surfaces of the lateral three and a half fingers was present
  • • Ref: Gray’s Anatomy, 41 st edition, page no. 891
